abstract.p: John M DeCicco letter on taxing unsafe, gas-guzzling SUVs; say it would take implausibly high taxes to overcome market forces yielding profit margins of $10,000 or more (S)

block.p: Re ''Feeling Crash-Resistant in an S.U.V.'' (Op-Ed, May 16):

Robert H. Frank insightfully explains the conflict between public and private safety characterizing the sport-utility problem. Re ''Feeling Crash-Resistant in an S.U.V.'' (Op-Ed, May 16):

Robert H. Frank insightfully explains the conflict between public and private safety characterizing the sport-utility problem. Setting steeper, weight-based state motor vehicle fees and closing the light-truck loophole in the federal gas guzzler tax would certainly be helpful. But if taxation is our main solution to this moral dilemma, we're in trouble.

It would take implausibly large taxes to overcome market forces yielding profit margins of $10,000 or more. New safety standards addressing vehicle aggressivity and rollover, plus updated fuel-economy standards covering S.U.V.'s and other light trucks, are overdue regulatory solutions, essential to restore balance to an automotive marketplace now consumed by ''luxury fever'' run amok on the road.
The writer is a senior associate at the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy.
